prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We propose to observe CO (3-2) emission of a z=0.085 AGN at band 7 with array C34-4. The specifications are as following:
# Array Configuration
We will image CO (3-2) in Band 7 with the C34-4 configuration, reaching spatial scales of 0.32”-5.2” (0.5-8.3 kpc). At the smallest scales, we will be able to resolve molecular outflows similar to those observed previously, while on the largest scales we maintain sensitivity over the full narrow-line region size (using the size-luminosity relation of Liu et al. 2013).
# Spectral Set-up
Our primary spectral band is at a sky frequency of 319 GHz (rest 346 GHz). We choose a correlator mode of 1875 MHz (1739 km/s) FDM with spectral binning of 4 channels for 1.8 km/s resolution. We expect a total line width for these sources of about 500 km/s, fitting safely in the spectral band, while the outflow itself may be 100-200 km/s. Therefore, we plan to bin further during data reduction to a spectral resolution of ~100 km/s to achieve the S/N ratios quoted below. We also include a continuum Baseband at a sky frequency of 317 GHz (rest 344 GHz). This continuum band will be used to constrain the star-formation rate.
# Sensitivity
The desired sensitivity for the CO(3-2) line is set to 0.5 mJy per 100 km/s channel per beam in order to achieve a 5-sigma detection of molecular gas masses as low as10^7 solar masses in the outflow. For this estimation we adopt a CO (1-0) to H_2 mass conversion factor of X_CO= 0.4 x 10^20 cm^-2 (K km s^-1)^-1 from Bolatto et al. (2013), and assume a line ratio L′(CO 3-2)/L′(CO 1-0) =1, which is typical for AGN (and seen in our previous ALMA observations). From previous observations of obscured AGN selected from the same sample, the typical gas masses are ~10^9 solar masses (Villar-Martin et al. 2013). With such a conservative mass sensitivity limit of 10^7 solar mass, the CO (3-2) is very likely to be detected.
With an estimated continuum sensitivity of 0.09 mJy per beam, we expect to detect the continuum at > 6 sigma, assuming a star-formation rate of at least 10 solar-masses per year, which is at the lower end presented in Zakamska et al. (2004). We will be able to constrain the star-formation rate at 10 solar-mass per year accuracy, assuming the emitting region has an area of 4 kpc^2 and adopting SED template of star-forming galaxies from Rieke et al. 2009.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We believe that AGN feedback is an important element that regulates galaxy evolution. However, how and how often AGN affect the molecular gas, which is the star formation fuel, is largely unknown. We propose to search for molecular outflow in a sample of 5 luminous obscured AGN from a well-studied SDSS sample. They are selected as the most luminous (log(L_[OIII]/L_sun)>8.7) local (z < 0.1) AGN with no selection regarding star-formation (IR) or jet (radio) activity, representing an unbiased AGN sample. As the central quasar is naturally obscured, their ionized gas can be easily studied, providing a more complete picture of multi-phase AGN outflows. We use the CO (J=3-2) line in Band 7 to achieve sub-parsec angular scale with sensitivity probing down to 10^7 M_sun molecular mass, essential to resolve and detect molecular outflow. With these observations, we can explore the properties and occurrence rates of molecular outflows in AGN, and study their relation with ionized outflow, towards understanding the role of AGN in shaping galaxy evolution.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Astrophysical Sciences Department and Observatory, Princeton University

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Astrophysical Sciences Department and Observatory, Princeton University
Dept of Physics & Astronomy, Johns Hopkins University
